posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4426867
>>4426870
I think so long as you're doing it in a way that works for low-pressure injection, it should work fine. Expecting the reaction-based ones to work with diffusers et al like pressurized bottles would be making it difficult.

https://youtu.be/rg1u-XVMU3Q?t=481
This would be the way to do it, IMO. All the CO2 is there and none of it is 'wasted' or fails to diffuse in time. You can change the diffusion rate by using a narrower bottle with less surface air, or increase it by using a larger bottle and place it near some turbulent flow.
With CO2 bottles there's 3 diffusion settings; too much, looks about right and the bottle is off - because filling a bottle is so cheap compared to the upfront cost that it's not really a concern as it would be with DIY where there is a lot more labour required.
Just my 2 cents.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In reference to the OP, I recently had a power outage that lasted from 1am Saturday to 10pm Saturday. Apparently 10 inches of rain over 12 hours was too much for my end of the neighbourhood.

My "1500" UPS with 1 year old batteries unfortunately only lasted 7 hours and beeped at me enthusiastically around 8. I'd plugged a box fan into it last week because I was too lazy to find an extension cord. Would've lasted double that with only 2 canister filters and an air pump.
Ended up connecting the filters ass to mouth by splicing in a 12v DC pump run off a backup car battery and just used a couple powerbanks to power a pair of 5v USB water pump for surface turbulence in my smaller tanks.

I've got enough shit lying around that I could run everything off 12V in a roundabout way, but I'll be budgeting this year for some LiFePO4, MPPT charger and an inverter. Got a bunch of monocrystalline solar cells laying around that would work.

>>4426967
I'm one of the biggest over stockers on here I'd bet, but you should probably cull the platys down to 2-3 again. Take the rest to lfs or petco and they'll take them, won't give you anything likely but you don't have to kill them at least. Also probably need more filtration - it looks like you have a matten overflow, which has potential to be a very good filter, is the filtration section entirely packed with media?

Betta will definitely get some fry to slow the pop growth down the line, but crowntails are fucking slow so may not get all of them. I wouldn't expect it to actually kill any adult platys, just make the attempt now and again.

I'd also get some more plants, if I were you. Stem plants like anacharis or hornwort are super easy and fast growing, bolbitis ferns offer a nice contrast to the Java fern, anubias or buce are always easy and popular, etc. But you really would benefit from some more places for various fish to hide and to get away from each other.

Beyond looking better than a tub just sitting there im also hoping the shell will act as sort of an insulation from rapid temperature changes, it's a rather dark tub and it's more likey to get hot here than to freeze. As for what is going in there besides Medaka, I have a Water Lily/water onion bulbs to put in to a Dirted planter I have, a good bit of Hornwort, My indoor aquarium plants came with tank herpies aka duckweed So Ive been gathering every single one I can find and putting them in to a cup for spring along with some other tank plant clippings. I plan to also have a Venus flytrap growing out of one side of the tank so it can eat the adult mosquitos while the fish get the larvae I also will be making the breeding mops, just in case I can at least break even if not pay for the hobby going forward. I also have a much smaller indoor grow out tub/QT.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4428275
Ick spreads by spores falling off the infected fish while it swims around. With it being so infested its shedding spores constantly. With the treatment seemingly being effective on the other Tetras but not that one, it most likely has some kind of underlying issue that the others do not have. You are taking out any carbon you have in the tank right? it will absorb the meds out of the water.

How I see it you have 3 choices.

>Keep treating the whole tank and hope you are not stuck in an endless cycle.
Keep in mind that meds stress out fish. So even if you have fish that are not currently sick you might cause them to get sick by stressing them out.

>ISO the one/s that are in really bad shape and target treat them, while ensuring the main tank does not flare up again
Isoing a schooling fish is gonna stress it out alot, it might make it worse and maybe kill it faster, but it also wont be spreading quite so many spores to everything else.

>euthanize the sick fish.
You've given it and it's school the proper treatment. It's the only one that is not making noticeable improvement and is a risk of keeping the infection in the tank

Don't add new fish while you're treating an illness, that's pretty much guaranteeing they'll get infected.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4428310
I would wait until everything is cleared up and then another month or so to make sure nothing pops back up before adding something new.

It sucks I know but you know what happens when something goes wrong and how it could spiral out of control. Better to make sure everything you currently have is safe before adding something new.

When getting something new set up a quarantine tank. it does not even need to be an actual fish tank. a plastic storage big with a small heater and an airstone is enough

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4428263
Within gardening, at least in the US, the two are synonymous - one of the best composts sold locally is mostly lobster. In the context of walstad tank, the idea is to have the maximum starting level of nutrients in the substrate, plus the microfauna and bacteria that naturally come with it.

Basically, doesn't matter and either will work, just make sure it's entirely natural compost/soil without a bunch of long life chemicals as the source of nitrogen. And then let that bitch run for a couple months before you add anything but snails.

They are derpy little things that have issues that should be taken in to account.
They tend to go blind due to being inbred to hell and back. They are not fast swimmers. >>4417092
Most of the slower growing more arid new world species are supposed to tolerate it pretty well, basically your Aphonopelma, Grammostola and Brachypelma and probably some of the less common genera from similar climates. That said, you always want to do it as close to the ground as possible because they're extremely fragile and you also want to make sure to check the temperament before you try to handle by gently touching the animal with a brush or something.

Overall I'd still recommend against it though, the animal gets nothing out of it and there's always a pretty significant risk of killing it if anything goes wrong

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4422334
Their availability nowadays isn't so bad, but I guess their prices vary a lot between Europe and the US. In EU you can get L2 for 12-16€ each, while I've seen Americans ask for like $40 which I guess discourages people from buying larger groups to breed themselves and help making them more accessible.

I think their care is managable if you already have some mantis experience and are dedicated, but it's a species where it's really best to go all in and keep a group in a large setup and eventually try to breed them. Throughout the nymph stages they aren't even that bad, they just need it hot and dry in a well-ventilated cage. Once they are subadult it gets more tricky because they need a lot higher humidity and the final molts are just generally risky and ultimately involve some luck to not go badly, which is why keeping a bunch of them helps so that a mismolt doesn't completely screw you over. When I kept them I self-built netcages with branches glued to the top for better gripping during molts, that worked quite well. Breeding just didn't work out for me because I ended up with only one male, who grew faster than the females and was already a geriatric by the time they became ready to mate and he couldn't connect despite his willingness to do so.

Other empusids like Blepharopsis mendica and Gongylus gongylodes are cool alternatives that are less expensive and demanding, but somewhat similar to them.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4428804
>>4428834
Shorter is fine, I'll definitely look into those species, thanks! I assume all of them do well with high humidity/high ventilation? Probably going to be about 75F/70% humidity long-term, though I can run humidity a bit lower for mantises.

Any of the colorful ones that can live in a group or that aren't stupid hard to care for? I've had some big ass green mantises as a kid in South Carolina, so was hoping for little more of an "exotic" look.

If the answer is no that's fine too, I liked the big ass mantis I had and long term it's going to be bumblebee toads if I can ever find them for sale again, or some darts or a small chameleon. I just love building bioactive ecosystems, and the awesome colors and textures that are possible with mixed tropical plants.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4428948
If you can drop daytime humidity to about 50-60% you could do a group of Phyllocrania paradoxa. Very frequently available, very easy to care for, calm and low cannibalism risk in a sizable tank with good structures and enough food. The females also can have a variety of colorations.

The rainforest species that can be kept communally are on the smaller side, some pretty hard to care for and possibly also hard to get, maybe not even available in the US. They would ideally also have some degrees higher temperature. Those would be mantids like Haania sp., Stenophylla lobivertex, Astyliasula phyllopus, or Ceratomantis sp.. Odontomantis would also work and should be more commonly available, but they're really small as adults and pretty basic looking mantids after all.

Not for groupkeeping, but as a bigger, exotic looking rainforest species you could also consider a Deroplatys desicatta/trigonodera/lobata/truncata or Parablepharis kuhlii. They look really nice and at least for mantis standards their lifespans tend to be a bit on the longer side. A slightly higher temp range of about 77-81F would be good for those though.

Also make sure that your tank's ceiling is covered in mesh, mantids will frequently strife towards higher spots and will end up hanging from the top in captivity a lot of the time. That also gives them convenient space for molting.

This thread is dedicated to all animals of the reptilia and amphibia classes. Topics include, but are not limited to: geckos, snakes of all kinds, frogs, salamanders, newts, turtles, tortoises, and much more. Before asking a question, do a search on the internet to see if it has been answered
Classifieds for finding breeders and products:
>morphmarket.com
>kingsnake.com
>faunaclassifieds.com
>reptilescanada.com (Canadian breeders)
>caudata.org
Most forums will have a "for sale" section on them, so look for that, especially if you have a specific herp you want. Craigslist can also be a good source for cheap aquariums, and make sure to check for any reptile expos that occur in your area.

When asking a question, make sure to include these details:
>Type and size of animal
>Enclosure dimensions
>Humidity and temperature
>Type of substrate
>The decor you use
>How often you feed
>The type of food you use
>If your animal is wild caught or captive bred
>How often you handle
>Who you bought the animal from

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Might be a dumb question but, biologically speaking, is there not a lot of significant difference between Reptiles and Amphibians? I have seen the same reptile owners keep amphibians too. And Herpetology itself seems to be concerned with both, why is that? Why aren't seperate like study of other animal classes?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4425471
Amphibians are more basal than reptiles, in that they existed first and eventually an amphibian developed a thicker non-permeable skin, and a shell around its eggs so they wouldn't dry out and eventually didnt need to hang out in the water as much if at all. Older biology had less to do with species development and more to do with "what does it look like, where does it live, and what does it do" though, so they just kind got lumped in together.
From a petkeeping perspective, the care of reptiles and amphibians is pretty similar (diets are similar in a lot of cases, need to build a little environment for them whose parameters are generally similar) so there's some crossover there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4425471
Amphibians and reptiles are divided by as many years of evolution as amphibians and mammals, and that is more years than the division between mammals and reptiles. But their ways of life and their metabolism are less diverged from those times than are mammals or the archosaur subgroup of Reptiles.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4426940
colubrids in general are more active than boids or pythons so it's less "here is a big sock filled with jello, it might climb on you" and more "hold on to this rope that constantly wants to move forward." treadmilling and allowing the snake to weave around your hand and arm is the name of the game. He is always going to want to go SOMEWHERE and/or investigate SOMETHING so will probably not be down for chill hangouts.
In terms of handling tolerance, even after you get him used to you being around and even get him to the point where he'll climb onto you voluntarily, if they dont want to go somewhere they dont want to go somewhere. The goal in that case is to wire into his head that nothing bad happens when you pick him up, and the best way to do that is to pick him up (standard snake handling rules apply - confident gentle scoop, first third to half of the body, dont hesitate or move too fast because either looks like predator behavior), inspect him a little bit, then let him go back inside the enclosure and leave him to his business for the rest of the day, repeating every day to every other day until the snake is just like "oh yeah okay it's you," then do it like once or twice a week or so to reinforce.
Note you'll want to do this when he's awake and active, ripping up a hide and grabbing a snake is a real good way to convince a snake you're going to kill it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4426857
Morphmarket. I got him for about $1300 at age 4 months. There's two varieties of emerald tree boas... amazon basin and northern. Amazon Basin have a continuous stripe down their back and are longer (7-9 foot) with a more calm demeanor and attitude. These are the super expensive ones people collect and breed morphs of like ball pythons.

Northern variety are a little shorter (5-6 foot range) and have a worse attitude. They can still be worked with but its a lot more effort. They have a broken pattern down their back and aren't usually collected as much. This results in northern variety being cheaper.

Mine is a Northern, because a captive bred baby will cost between $1000-2000 for a northern, but $6-10000 for an amazon basin. I just didnt find the extra cost worth it. My little guy is great despite being northern. The breeder I got him from was real small time guy but they are certainly out there.

But also definitely make sure whatever you buy is captive bred, not captive born. Ask for pictures of the parents and whatever information you can get to try to verify they are actually captive bred. A lot of dealers will put "CB" so people think that means captive bred, when its actually captive born. These are just still wild ETBs that have had their eggs stolen and born in captivity. This doesn't help with their temperament. They need to be born of captive parents, preferably of parents who were themselves captive bred.

>is it possible for fish populations to recover while we still maintain high levels of wild fishing?
Depends on the species, Some species have a fast lifecycle and are highly prolific but others take a long time to reproduce. I think the future lies in protecting aquatic habitats and breeding grounds so the prolific species can continue being abundant for extraction combined with aquaculture so we can make not so prolific species more prolific by reducing mortality and other factors. There is also selective breeding and GMOs and we might produce for example tuna that grows faster and taste better.

Doing my dissertation on this right now. It's an absolute fucked industry. Salmon farming is the big one. The problem is literally every sea pen of salmon is infested with salmon lice that essentially eat the fish alive until it's body gives up. Because the salmon are so packed together it's like a breeding factory for lice which can then drift out of the pens and infect wild salmon.
Farmed salmon get treatment for the lice ( which is also fucked. Thermolicers are hot water treatments that essentially micro cook the salmon while alive to kill the lice), but wild salmon obvs get nothing and 1-2 lice will kill a juvenile salmon easy. Wild salmon populations are essentially non recoverable because salmon farming won't end bc it's too tasty.
Profits are plummeting for some companies rn because of literally microjellyfish floating in and killing half the stock, so salmon prices are probably gonna spike soon.
Also, wild fact. Salmon farms in Scotland eat more food mass per day than the human population of the entire UK. And less fun, salmon farms were started to reduced wild fishing, but 2/3 of salmon food is wild caught fish. So what's the fucking point.

>>4429546
There is no consensus on that sort of thing. Scientists differ widely in their philosophies regarding that sort of thing. Some think that returning an ecosystem to a historical state is better, while others focus more on how an ecosystem functions overall rather than the 'uniqueness' of the species involved in that ecosystem.

So if a captive bred species X performs the exact same functions in the ecosystem as a historical/wild species X it is fine. Or even replace with a different species that does exactly the same thing. E.g. a fly that has sligtly different shaped penis but still does the same thing as a different species.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4414174

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4414174
Sign up to birds of the world. I think it's $40 a year with a first year discount. That is the ultimate resource for everything science knows about every bird species. Some listings are sparse on details because the birds have never been studied but anything common has full info on behaviour, reproduction, migration, evolution, range, plumage, diet, everything, with citations. It's much more in depth than ebird and allaboutbirds. It's all text content but they link to sounds and images.

I would always google stuff and find mixed answers or no clear answer. Google isn't really good for researching birds, it's a niche topic and the algorithm isn't good at translating bird searches into relevant results. BOW solved that for me. There's no app but if you pin the site to your home screen it works fine on mobile.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's the link https://birdsoftheworld.org/bow/subscribe

They have a few you can look at for free. It's $49 a year. For me the subscription is worth it, I don't use it every day but when I want to know anything about my birds it has the answer. Or just ask here and if I see the post I'll look it up lol.

posts.com: Newly hatched cuckoos push the other eggs out of the nest. It's a built in instinct, so the bird that built the nest both thinks it's her child and takes more care of it (more food etc). Not all bird species can tell by looking that a baby bird isn't theirs, they just know it was in their nest so they raise it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

the cuckoos comes back periodically to check on their baby/egg. If the surrogates either removed the egg or something got to the baby the cuckoo will destroy their nest and kill their chicks. I'm guessing this kind of insurance behavior to stop the ones that are wise to their shit from breeding

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.com: tips for bird watching? im a newbie and i never seem to see any birds except at the neighbors house i see some backyard birds (doves, cardinals, sparrows, bluejays) because they have a feeder. when i go to the park i hear birds all over but don’t see any. should i scatter some seeds?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: These two were the product of a mourning dove pair nesting in a hanging plant, the last time I saw them

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4427863
I'm quite a beginner too, but here are my thoughts. I wouldn't scatter seeds at the park. It's cool to set up feeders at home to observe birds, but in a public spot it can be disruptive. The biggest thing I learned is to be patient. I'll hike around the park and hear a lot but not see anything, but then I'll slow down a bit or sit/stand in one spot for a while and I'll start to see some stuff. It's also fun to learn which birds are common in different areas or parks and then learn more about those birds and their habits to increase your chances of spotting them. You really get out what you put in when it comes to birding.

>>4359128
Snowy owls are one of the few animals that unironically ignite my moé instincts. Not only do they look like adorable little angels, they also have the personalities of ones as well. Chick-on-chick infanticide is relatively rare in this species, and on top of that the siblings are known to share their given meals with each other. All the more impressive taking into consideration that they live in an environment that is only slightly more forgiving than the polar ice caps, or planet Hoth.

The species are sexually dimorphic to better suit their familial roles. The male is nearly solid white to blend into the tundra helping him to hide, but that also aids him in hunting lemmings. While the female is a speckled guardian who broods on a nest above permafrost, usually while tenderly pruning her offspring. However, like all parents the will fight beak and claw if any intruder ventures too close, from arctic foxes to polar bears, to the typical human.

If the don't melt your heart, I don't know what will.

Although this image looks like amateur clickbait, prehistoric Crete was a topsy-turvy place featuring elephants and owls the size of goats. The said owls were flightless, long-legged stalkers that pounce on unsuspecting prey, and even in (relatively) modern times Crete was known for lacking in any major carnivores. There was even a myth saying Hercules went on a mass exterminating crusade on the island to honor his literal god father Zeus.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4372256
That is an excellent question for multiple reasons:

1. It will be a fun project to reconstruct the vocal cords of this animal, there was even a YouTube video speculating on how T.Rex most likely sounded like a double bass, due to modern birds (of the large variety) using closed mouth vocals to communicate over a large distance, similar to elephants.

2. But on a more opinionated note. I find it disappointing that there was no grand designs towards this animal, and it reminds me of the enthusiastically, cheesy early iguanodon interpretations. It's better to imagine the creature as a 19th century Godzilla while being based on a single jawbone, rather than a lackluster paragraph on Wikipedia. Imagination is important to tell stories and to fill in the intellectual gaps, (as long as there is systematic evidence).

Crete is an underrated paleo landscape were big was small and vise versa, and it's eerie to think that the ancient Greeks noted the lack of hostile fauna of the island, and they all seemed to have disappeared like the Minoans.

>>4427092
I had a vision in my sleep last night. As distinguished from a dream which is mere sorting and cataloguing of the day's events by the subconscious. This was a vision, fresh and clear as a stream in Central Kalimantan- the mind revealing itself to itself. In my vision, I was on the veranda of a vast feeding platform, a Peron Makan of some fantastic proportion.
There seemed to emanate from it a light from within - this gleaming radiant jungle. I had known this place. I had in fact been born and raised there. This was my first return, a reunion with the deepest wellsprings of my being. Wandering about, I was happy that the forest had been immaculately maintained. There had been planted a number of additional trees, but in a way it blended so seamlessly with the original canopy, one would never detect any difference. Returning to the jungle's grand treescape, there came a knock from above. Budi was standing there. He was happy and care-free, clearly living a life of deep harmony and joy. We embraced - a warm and loving embrace, nothing withheld. We were in this moment one. My vision ended. I awoke with a tremendous of optimism and confidence in pongos and their future.

I had one in my headlights a few hours ago. On the side of the road, in the spotlight, a doe squatted and urinated at about 30ft from me. Had a stare off with my headlights. When I turned them off, she initially sped off, but came back just 5 minutes later. Closing in, I spooked her at about 6 feet by telling her she was brave, meeting a scary human.

Left her some salty snacks, away from the road.

Had a meet and greet with some highland cows, they were skiddish, was a bit sketchy. Saw "my" herd of semi wild cows as well, got to spend a while near them, their smell probably masking my human scent. By doing that, got to see a few deer grazing up close. Without the cows, they'd sped off without me knowing about it.

Next to the deer and the cows, got to pet a friendly bull as well, no kicks or hornplay, so that went well. Bit of an understatement to say it went well. Anyhoo, deer. They are cute.

>>4417067
A strong rat trap, not one of those wimpy plastic ones. Peanut butter, rancid if you have some, they just can't help themselves. If you're a compassionate soul, set them (get at least half a dozen) when you're around and wait to hear the snap, then immediately go over to it and bash the poor things head in with a heavy object (I use a big automotive wrench). Oftentimes the trap breaks the lower spine, not the neck and causes the little vermin a great deal of pain before it finally dies. It is absolutely necessary to kill them as soon as you can, and in my mind, if you must kill, do it quickly and cleanly as you can. If you can see one, there are probably several you don't see, so keep setting traps until it's been days since you got one. Let me reiterate, it is absolutely imperative that you kill all of them as soon as you can. If you hesitate or show mercy, not only will they fuck your world, you will end up having to kill far far more of them in the future. I am listening to rat scratches in the ceiling right now. I didn't have the heart to kill a rat, and now I've been killing scores of it's descendants every week for the past six months. The whole property is lousy with them. I'm like mouse Hitler at this point lol. Don't be like me anons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4428514
Cats purr as kittens to know when their littermates are close without being noisy. They're growing fast and the frequency they resonate at promotes bone and muscle growth and healing.
After they stop being kittens they will occasionally still purr, but its usually a self soothing technique when they're hurt or ill.
Domestic animals have a bit of arrested development, and so your cat will continue to purr because it gets a response from you.

>>4424001

Wife and I bred our dog and raised the litter of puppies, we ended up keeping one boy and one girl from the litter. Boy has been harder to potty train, but is just as good at learning commands so far. Boys will be worse with humping/marking, girls will bleed. You can neuter/spay to address those issues, but they will still probably hump a bit - they're dogs. Also, don't rush it if you want to neuter. It seems that even vets are pushing for earlier and earlier neutering, but neutering early can cause other health issues down the road.
Also, don't be swayed by saps who cuck for shelter adoption. They will try to convince you that being a responsible dog owner is all about adopting then neutering. I have a relative that was disgusted with me for breeding my dog because she saw every puppy I sold as a shelter puppy euthanized. But guess who was the one that got sent to the hospital after her shelter shitbull attacked? Understanding the breed will help you be able to take much better care of your dog, and shelter dogs just won't have the same consistency/predicability.

If your dog does not pull then a harness is a better option. If it pulls using a harness with a top clip will exacerbate the issue. He can pull harder and will want to pull more. Usually harnesses have a front clip as well. This can help with the pulling a fair bit, but training it out will obviously be better.

Also harnesses can come off a little more easily than a flat collar, so you may want to have both on just in case. The only time I've had a harness come off was when I was trying to keep him still to remove a burr or something.

Last thing is I really like how some harnesses have handles on them. Makes some situations a lot easier.

>>4427640
The reason Canines and Humans ended up becoming such good friends so early is because they're one of the few animals that can keep pace with us. Early hunter gatherers used persistence hunting, which is a tactic wolves in packs use. You're not going to outrun a spooked deer in a sprint, but if you just keep a steady pace, and keep tracking them, you can make up the difference over time, until you've exhausted the animal you're stalking and you can just all pile on the thing and break its neck or stove in its head.
They're muscles for endurance.
Cats on the other hand are typically ambush predators, and the whole tactic is reserving their energy for one big push to catch their prey.
Think of a cheetah. They're fast as fuck, but they don't keep that pace up for long.

Cats ARE much dumber than dogs, and they always will be. it's a neurological reality. They have fewer neurons, and the connections between them show that their brains are more oriented towards visual-motor skills. >>4429684
Their muscles are built differently. Cat muscles have a lot more fast twitch muscle fiber than dogs or people do. Which is why a cat can be a lazy piece of shit 99.9% of the time and then being able to swat a bird out of the air.
People and dogs have more long muscle fibers, which are better for endurance.
We all have both kinds, and certain muscles have more of one kind than the other, depending on what they do, but you can think of cats as having spring loaded muscles. A lot more power and energy released at once, but you have to "reset" the springs before they can go again. Your endurance muscles are more like pistons, made to keep going, and have more power to give over time, but with a less steep curve.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4428848
Everything you listed applies to pic-related as well. They have slit pupils and large whiskers because they are naturally nocturnal animals. They have large tails because they are for warmth protection, not balance. Saying they are more 'closer' to cats than wolves are to cats are (in terms of convergence) is true, but it's a fallacy. Nobody is saying that lions are closer to wolves than African wild cats are because they are larger and live in groups, even though this is also a true statement. It's this type of comparison which I think is inane.

>>4428851
Foxes aren't solitary in the same way wild cats are. Wild cats spend practically their entire adult life alone, as nomads, and their communication with others of their species mostly being done with territory and scent marking, and their physical encounters mostly involve fighting disputes or mating. Foxes and tanuki are social animals that live in groups, and typically have an established den or living area. They also are characteristically known for their social aspect of playing with each other for fun, wagging their tails, and their high range of vocalizations (barking, howling, whining, etc) which they use to communicate with each other. Foxes are naturally possess canine-like movement and behavior due to their biology. Just look at footage like this >>4427716 and tell me you can't see the difference.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4428091
That's an odd categorization. The ones who don't care about the breed are good people, while the ones who care are not? I don't see how that makes sense. Dog owners should understand the breeds they own and care about their working purpose. They should try to give their dog the kind of a lifestyle that dog was bred for. A person who doesn't research the breed they own doesn't sound like a good dog owner to me.

Either way, whether you love or hate dogs isn't an indicator of what kind of a person you are.
Someone who loves dogs might love them so much that they become a misanthrope and consider dogs more important than humans. They might become a hoarder and end up with so many dogs that they can't take care of them all properly. They might cover up bite incidents out of fear that their dogs would get taken away and euthanized. They might bring aggressive dogs into public spaces and put other people in danger.
Someone who hates dogs might hate them because they were bitten by one. They might live in a location where feral dogs shit everywhere, spread diseases, kill livestock and attack people. They might have lost a loved one in a dog attack.

Even if you love dogs, there are plenty of ways you might end up causing harm to either dogs or other people. And even if you hate dogs, that's not a bad thing if you simply avoid them instead of trying to hurt them.
Loving or hating dogs isn't the litmus test for being a good person. How you treat other people and animals is what matters.

If you rap your knuckles on the back of a wombat it's like knocking on a door.
When attacked by a predator wombats charge down their huge burrows and squat. The predator can't bite through their back so tries to climb over them to bite their head, then the wombat does a press-up and crushes the predator to death against the roof of the burrow.
If you hit a wombat with your car it will smash your sump cover up into your crankshaft.
If a wombat gives you a playful nip it can accidentally sever your achilles tendon.
Wombats also have square poop.
I'm not making any of this up.

>>4412779
Wombat poop is square because they have bones either side of their turd-cutter that force the feeshus into that shape.
There might be an evolutionary advantage in that it's harder for square poop to roll or be blown or washed away from where you want it to be. It's your advertising, like your Twitter or your Tinder or whatever.
Animals are weird everywhere. It's just the fact that Australia has been so long isolated from the northern-hempishere continents that marsupials (and monotremes) evolved to fill all the niches that placental mammals do everywhere else.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4413497
Sure, maybe. I'm not claiming to know.
Koalas, like wombats, have a backwards-facing pouch -- which is also downwards-facing in the case of the koala.
This is apparently because they descend from a common ancestor that burrowed like a wombat and didn't want dirt in its pouch.
The koala, though, has evolved a sphincter muscle around the top (bottom) of its pouch so that the baby koalas don't fall out 150 feet up a gum tree.

>>4412377
Dogs are great, but people underestimate how much active work they take.
Do a bunch of research and make sure you 100% understand what you are taking on.

Despite popular culture and all the jokes and what not, Cats show just as much affection and give you just as much love and attention as dogs do. They are just more subtle about it, but they will bond with you and be a friend for life.

Cats are a million times easier to keep as a pet, as they are far more independent.
If you feel like a dog is far too much work after your research, go to some pounds or rescues and find a kitten or young cat that just clicks with you.

Pets can absolutely help out loneliness.

RECOMMENDED READING LIST ON EVOLUTION:
> The Selfish Gene - Richard Dawkins
> The Extended Phenotype - Richard Dawkins
> The Revolutionary Phenotype - J.F. Gariepy
> Evolution and the Theory of Games - John Maynard Smith
> Animal Signals - John Maynard Smith
> The Red Queen - Matt Ridley
> Mendel's Principles of Heredity - Bateson & Mendel
> Population Genetics: A Concise Guide - John H. Guillespie
> The Largest Avian Radiation: The Evolution of Perching Birds, or the Order Passeriformes by Jon Fjeldså, Les Christidis, and Per G. P. Ericson
>The Cambrian Explosion: The Construction of Animal Biodiversity by Douglas Erwin
>Carboniferous Giants and Mass Extinction: The Late Paleozoic Ice Age World by George McGhee Jr.
>Triassic Life on Land: The Great Transition by Hans-Dieter Sues
>On the Prowl: In Search of Big Cat Origins by Mark Hallett and John Harris

IDK if this is the right thread because I don't frequent /an/, but I have a burning question: Based on what's known about Hypsilophodon, is it accurate for it to be this funny chicken that spits acid?
https://isle.fandom.com/wiki/Hypsilophodon

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4394215
That complex feathering is probably far beyond the filaments and proto-feathers that actually would have adorned the animal so it would have looked more like a plucked turkey.
>spits acid
We'll probably never be able to know something like that, though maybe the animal's teeth would show the effects of continuous exposure to stomach acid. It probably wouldn't be used as a blinding agent, but there are a number of birds that vomit on themselves or vomit on their attackers as a defensive mechanism. So It might have been possible that Hysilophodon could have used vomit oil in a similar way as Fulmar chicks or it could use a mix of spit and vomit to try and blind animals similar to camels.
Without any evidence of these behaviors in Hypsilophodon I can't really call it accurate, but it's not impossible for it to have used vomit as an anti-predator mechanism.

/tg/ tourist here:
How would you go about creating a slime life form thats biologically pausibile?
I've been working on a space setting where most lifeforms are not humanoid [spoiler] the plot/lore being that humanity despite expanding through the cosmos are already on the bringe of extinction, with the most optimistic numbers calculating that there's at best 1000 or so humans alive, even counting a place called "The Sanctuary" which is a small human zoo in the middle of an alien megatropolis that has tried to work on preservation programs, planet Earth being even to most humans just a myth and not even in some cases not even marked on galactic maps [/spoiler] making humans more unique

I've been trying to do some and one idea I had was that of slime life that uses mecha containers to move in places that's not their world similar to picrel (altho that's more of a dieselpunk magic magma creature)
I don't wanna do everything 100% realistic but grounded instead so Im looking for inspiration
Thanks for the help in advance

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4400460
You want to qualify these questions:
>What level of nervous system do they have? Unicellular, Cnidarianesque, Molluskesque, Tetrapodesque?
>Are they amorphous or semirigid? If they're amorphous, how do they protect themselves and navigate the world? How do they manipulate the world? Semirigid will have a much easier time here.
>How did they attain intelligence and tool use, and how well-versed in it are they? Are they more intelligent and well-situated for whatever niche they inhabit, or are they really good at using tools but not the biggest brainiac?
My personal recommendation is to go with a cephalopod-esque intelligence and make them deep-sea dwellers that can contort their bodies easily but discovered tool use as an excellent way to preserve them and their kin. You can easily make whalefalls/driftwood equivalents more common on their home world for native materials and a source for them to tread upwards. Bonus: deep-sea dwelling creatures often survive trips to the surface easily, so it would make them look even more blobbish but without any risks to their functionality. It would also give them precedence for wearable devices or containers for respiration or similar so you can move forward with your initial idea if you so choose. Just remember to not make them literal octopus/squids. Try searobins+blobfish as the basis, maybe.

I have an idea though it's evolutionarily dodgy imo.

First off, we have real slime life forms on earth: slime molds. Despite being single celled organisms that don't have anything even close to a brain they're apparently capable of some degree of cognition (see: https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/04/160427081533.htm?trendmd-shared=0). Even better for you, they're capable of fusing together into super-cells and apparently can share that knowledge (see: https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/12/161221090246.htm)
I hope you're serious about it not being 100% realistic because here's were it gets a little dodgy, lets pretend that enough of them fuse together allows to develop something approaching or even surpassing human intelligence either with this weird cell memory or using millions of cell nuclei as some kind of central nervous system or maybe having some kind of unique organelles to function as a cns. Either way, they're still basically a living puddle of snot so they'd need some kind of powered exoskeleton to do much of interest but I'm not sure how they'd make one in the first place regardless of what their environment is like. Maybe they got some help from some other species and have since gained independence.

Started to play around with domestication yesterday. Vucum's ch'ceri means 'friend of the people' and is a very trusting creature. It's been bred into two types: tinur [working] and cssin'rt'ust [transportation]. It's also the only species whose back legs fused due to a mutation that just stuck around. It allows for greater pushing/pulling strength.
The plant came to me in a dream. Its spikes have red tips and are coated in poison, fresh leaves are blood red and slowly become light green. It's about four meters tall and lives in tight rain forests where the spikes, once piercing neighbouring plants, kill them to make room for more sunlight.
The two things on the left are scrapped concepts because I feel like they're not very creative. Bottom one was supposed to be a domesticated later evolution form of the one above. Markings are drawn on, not natural. Front pair of legs developed into tough claws to fight off opponents and grab small prey.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've been thinking about how aquatic mammals could come across a large, distant island that no other large mammals have yet colonized, and re-evolve a terrestrial lifestyle (nevermind the awkward wobbling pinnipeds already do). I have three main questions about this idea:

- What pressures would there be for pinnipeds (the most likely candidate; cetaceans would be too anatomically awkward) to evolve terrestriality? Sure, with little to no competition, they can radiate like hell with all the new food sources give a couple million years, but what would convince a population of them to totally leave the water?

- I've noticed that practically all aquatic mammals (besides otters, I guess) have blubber. Why is that - how necessary is it? I can see it being necessary for cold temperate waters, but what about sunbaked tropical coastal waters? Would it be possible for a population of pinnipeds to become "skinny" again if they keep to warm tropical waters?

- How plausible is it for the hind flippers to become more "leg-like" and aid in terrestrial locomotion?

I think you're deliberately being wrong or are just being misinformed.

Spinosaurus was most likely a shoreline hunter rather than a semi-aquatic pursuit swimmer. It's actual build and sail would inhibit it from actually swimming all that fast. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Based on the proportion of fossil finds, sauropods were the most prolific of dinosaur fauna from the Jurassic and early Cretaceous; not the equivalent of large, rare animals like elephants, rhinos, or hippos, but rather, the sauropods were the densely herding animals like wildebeest, buffalo, or zebras that dominated the ecosystem. No ornithischian was ever as populous as the sauropodomorphs until the mid-late Cretaceous when hadrosaur and ceratopsian biomass became the dominant presence. It is the long-necked Diplodocus or Camarasaurus that herded in the hundreds, thousands, or millions across the Jurassic North American prairie like the bison, not the Dryosaur or Camptosaur.

>Why across almost life as we know it does it always involve a male fugging a female?
It doesn’t maybe life (you) know about but not most life known by mankind.
In some organisms all individuals produce motile gametes that are basically the same. Both are released in water and when they meet fertilization occurs. In some creatures having assimetric gametes (one being larger and less mobile and the other smaller specialized in motility) was selected, us included. Since we call the ones with the motile gamete males and the big gamete females in our species we started calling this male and female gametes even if in many species the same individual produces both. In microbes we call plasmid transference as sexual reproduction but it is a completely different process from human sexual reproduction, it doesn’t combine half of its entire genome with half of the entire genome of the other to create a third individual also the one donating the dna can become the receptor of a different one and this trade can even happen in unrelated microbes of different genera. There is a freshwater species where some males produce a sperm with its full DNA and instead of combining with the egg and producing a progeny that is a mix of both it yeets the egg dna and make a progeny that is a copy of the “male” (they are actually produce both so there aren’t really males and females)

XX and XY is the human mode, some species it is the other way around, and have males with symmetrical chromosomes and females with asymmetrical. Some species have a X0 system where one have two copies and the other only one. Other species like bees and ants unfertilized eggs become males and fertilized ones become females meaning that males have half the number of chromosomes than females. The platypus have W, X and Y chromosomes with WY, WX, or XX females and YY or XY males. Animals like alligators and turtles the sex is determined by the temperature of incubation and not by their genome. We have also sex determined by other ambient factors and even sex determined by social status like in the clownfish where the biggest and strongest fish around is the female and all the others are males, if the female dies the biggest and strongest male of the harem becomes female. Other animals start male and becomes female as they get older.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's been explained now why it exists, but also it allows for increased genetic diversity, better control over the rate of genetic mutations, and increased protection against the decay of genes.
This is important when dealing with things like diseases/viruses, which are going to attack specific genes. Certain populations, through reproducing sexually, may pass around traits that prevent specific diseases from working on them. Or certain genes may be changed that can no longer be targeted. As you may know, if a population is genetically identical as a result of asexual reproduction, they are increasingly susceptible to disease, as they all share the same genes that can be targeted.

posts.com:
>>4426646
The fact that it create greater variability on both instead of having one be more variable refutes that. Sexual reproduction helps combining and shuffling genes. Imagine that a biological process have 5 steps A, B, C, D and E.
Now let's say an individual got a random mutation of Step A that makes it more efficient so we will call this individual Blue. Now its descendants will have an advantage over the other lineages. Now Let's say a different individual (I'm calling this Red) got a mutation on step B, its descendants also will have an advantage over the other lineages. Without sexual reproduction these two will compete for resources and the most efficient one will become dominant. Now if you add a way to transfer genes between individuals now those lineages can combine generating descendants with varied combinations of of genes, some will have none of the mutations, some will have only one and others will have both. In this case having both makes an individual better than both parents, this is the greatest advantage of sexual reproduction, to achieve the same result without it every individual lineage would need to get the right mutation for each gene instead of borrowing it from a different lineage and a good gene might be lost if it appeared in a less efficient strain that already is dying. What you described would be closer to animals like aphids or daphnia where they reproduce asexually most of the time generating many individuals with a stable genome and reproduce sexually from time to time. Also some species lost sexual reproduction entirely despite descending from ancestors who performed sexual reproduction only.

posts.com: Pic related was a very sweet kitty that used to roam around my home. We occasionally fed and petted him, and he was very fond of us. Seemed like the perfect house kitty. I always thought of taking him to the vet to get shots and maybe a flea bath so we could try to find a home for him, since it isn't possible for us to have cats at the time. Unfortunately, he went missing a couple of months ago. Pic was from the very last time we saw him. I wanted to believe someone opened their doors to him, but I have to be realistic. It ain't safe out there for a mild mannered kitty like him. I feel so guilty for not taking action sooner. I recently came across two other extremely sweet kitties who don't seem to have a home. How can I help them without breaking the bank?

If you want ducks, just handcatch them. Feed them, gain their trust. Give them bread, first some floating bits, when you have them within reach, squish the bread so that it sinks.

When they start diving for it, throw a few sinking pieces, grab them when they stick their heads under.

I used to do this to stop the ducks from trying to eat my fishing bait, just hold one (male for best results-) upside down for the rest to see. Then release, no problems for the rest of the day.

Or keep them, free pets/food.

I’ve owned like every breed of domestic duck and also some exotic ones like mandarins and wood ducks. Never had an issue with aggression. In domestic ducks drakes will only pick on other birds because they’re trying to rape them. They’re certainly a lot more docile to each other than chickens.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4400543
They have random personalities and males will fight like roosters will.
We have a male that was raised with chickens and he fucking despises our chickens and will chase them. Another male call duck is tiny as hell but will try and nip at your ankles. The rest are pretty chill.
Depending on the drake you will need 2-4 hens for him. Otherwise they will literally breed the poor females to death. Although sometimes you can get away with one to one ratios.
Call ducks especially pair off well, but don't like swimming like other ducks and prefer just to splash in shallow puddles and dishes.
Our one bossy female call duck is pretty funny since she will quack very loudly if her flock gets more than a few feet from her. They will then circle back to her.
Also if they aren't making a nest ducks will lay eggs wherever they fucking want. So keep that in mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4403365
Ours did pretty well nesting, but we never let them hatch since we had enough birds at the time. Only thing to keep in mind is to make sure their area is fairly good size.
When the ground is wet and muddy ducks will bury their beaks in them and look for bugs. Problem is that this will add up and soon their pen will be full of small holes everywhere. Because they are some of the largest ducks if they step in one of those holes they can hurt their legs. Ducks have very fragile legs and larger ones especially.
We have an old drake that hurt his leg and doesn't move much. Honestly surprising he has made it this long.

>GOD TIER
Landrace working breeds that aid man. Their breed standard is is a four point list
"Stay out of the vets office"
"Don't kill your owners other animals"
"Don't bite your owners child"
"Get the job done"
Alaskan huskies, NZ huntaways and heading dogs, farm collies (not the designer breed), actual australian cattle dogs (not the AKC bred ones stateside), caucasian LGDs, middle eastern sighthounds, and the working stock of hunting hounds like blue laceys are great examples of this. Despite being "working" dogs, they're casual employees. They actually make good pets because of their stable temperaments well adapted to going days, weeks, or even months with no work to do.

The original and the ideal dogs of the honest man, before industrialization destroyed society. If you need more constant work just rotate dogs so they last longer. They hunt, they hred, they protect, they work.

>OKAY TIER
Everything that isn't in shit tier. I guess your australian shepherd and standard poodle aren't totally useless and don't die that easily, usually!

>ABSOLUTE SHIT TIER MUST BE EXTERMINATED
Any dog bred to harm man or be used for illegal activity. Mutts with no purpose and unstable, dangerous temperaments. Any individual mutt or purebred with ill health. All of these must be culled for the good of all dogs. Contamination from inferior genes (ie: most pitbulls) can set dog breeding back tens of thousands of years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4419237
I guess it really depends. Especially if you get a kitten. There's a chance if you get a cat he will be a house plant you need to feed, but theres a bigger chance the cat is a much larger part of your life then you think it would be.

I got my cat during covid when he was 3 months old, and I spent every second with him. We grew a huge bond because he was the only living thing I saw daily, but he imprinted on me to such a degree where he is extremely comfortable around people (when I go to the vet they can't believe how well behaved he is, he isn't scared at all to be picked up or examined) and is very social. But I know he's like this because I was in his life constantly.

Anyways, because of this, he needs love and affection, not just food. He wants to play, cuddle, be pet, etc. I talk to him and he talks back, and we spend time at my apartment together a lot. I care about his health and weight so I feed him wet food every 8 hours, so thats definitely a routine I have to follow for his sake. But when I get home he's happy, and I'm happy to see him. I feel like the answer to your question is more how much you want your cat to be part of your life. Assuming you get a kitten (which you need to have a lot of time for at the beginning) every cat can become fun little kitties. Older cats usually are more set in their ways, but they have their routines and know what they want, so you dont have to constantly analyze and raise a kitten. I'll say this, watching him grow up was truly surreal. Seeing how small he was when I got him where he had to climb up his scratching post, to being taller than it. Him being able to make jumps he couldn't before, getting stronger while playing, there truly is nothing like it. Hope I've given you some insight, familia.

When you feed him observe if he gorges on his food. If he vomits not long after eating he probably ate too fast.

Ask your vet if you're concerned.

>test with foxes to see which one was the most docile towards humans
No, they bred it to be docile. Docile and emotionally attached are not the same thing. Attachment theory comes from child development studies. For example, an emotionally attached child is expected to have separation anxiety when its parent is gone, then feel less stressed and willing to explore a new environment when their parent returns, using the parent as a "secure base". Cats demonstrate similar behavior with their owners.

Dogs have a strong musky odor that is typically only comforting for their owner and is overpowering to everyone else.

With cats there is the litter box, but typically the bad smells from cats are because their owners don't clean the litter box.

First off you should neuter him, that would def maximize the chances because neutered cats don't spray and have a reduced aggressiveness/territoriality.
How many shelters are there in your area that have a no-kill policy? Do private non-profit organizations that could give you a hand (even if just to advertise the cat) exist?
>Would it be worth it to take him to a vet beforehand for a general checkup?
Yes. Imagine if someone is interested and asks you details about the cat and you can't be specific about his health... Even a cat lover who decides to adopt a less fortunate cat would like to have an idea of the health status of the cat they're about to adopt. The more presentable he is, the more chances he has.

I hope you can find a way anon.

Hopefully it's a short regimen so the pill pockets will continue to work
>They only work sometimes
You have to be extremely careful to handle them with clean (but not fragrant) hands and not touch the pill with the hand that handles the pocket - even a tiny bit of pill residue on the outside of it can make it smell/taste bad.

Pilling a cat sucks but is by no means impossible and is better than a sick cat, but it also isn't a great long-term option. Back when I was caring for my cat with cancer I had to give her bi-monthly prednisolone injections.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fleas are very visible, pic related. Look up a video online to get an idea of how to find them and how they move but you really can't mistake them if they're there. Get a comb or run your hand in the opposite direction of her fur, and not just around the area of the scabs, and if she has some you'd probably notice.
Scabs can be any number of things, though.
Yes they can scratch themselves bloody. My cat frequently does this on the lightly furred area above her eyes, but they generally look like cat scratches. Fairly long and thin lines of blood, not really what I'm envisioning when I hear the word scab.
Keep an eye on it. If it doesn't go away fairly fast for its size I'd take her in.

>>4427313
Because that stuff doesn't kill flea eggs, and fleas don't stay on the cat all the time.
Wash the cat's bedding and stuff in hot water, and dry it on high heat.
Might even be worth buying some flea powder for your carpet and upholstery. Its just a powder your sprinkle all over the place, let it sit for 15-30 minutes, and then vacuum it all up.
Fleas are a pain in the ass, I've had to deal with an infestation, and the best thing to do is strike first, and strike hard.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4422557
you clearly haven't done this before... when you bring a cat inside that has lived outdoors, there is a time period where they will beg to go outside, and shutdown/hide indoors. you gotta let them work that out. just provide food, and a quiet/calm environment for them inside until they get used to it. it can take anywhere from 48hrs to a couple of weeks, but they will adjust. all of my cats came from outdoors as strays, and they don't ever beg or act like they want to go outside anymore. as long as they have attention and a comfortable place at the window they will like it inside. I even have a cat that spent the first 3 or 4 years of it's life outside with next to no human contact. no issues as an indoor cat now. if they aren't spayed/neutered however, they will want to go outside and roam. get them fixed.

>>4396491
My guess is that South American Corvids aren't well suited to the climate/environment of Patagonia. Looking at the "List of birds of Brazil" Wikipedia page, it appears the only Corvids in Brazil belong to the genus Cyanocorax. A large portion of the range in the Corvidae range map seems to be due to the range of the genus Corvus (which makes up 1/3 of Corvid species) and according to its Wikipedia page it occurs "on all temperate continents except South America". Corvus would likely do quite well in temperate SA but it appears that Central America is the barrier preventing them from reaching it (I think Corvus corax is the closest in the Americas but its range stops in Nicaragua).

Okay, since our friends from /pol/ produced nothing but inane ramblings (as expected) let me give you some historical context.
Fair warning to the aforementioned /pol/acks – this is not going to be one of your meme pictures you use to “redpill” each other.
There will be a shitton of words words words, so you better leave right now since you don’t give a fuck about dogs, or truth in general.

Here we go
Back in ye olden days word "borzoi" was used to refer to any breed of sighthounds, and the specific borzoi breed of today would be called Russkaya psovaya borzaya,
or Russian silky\wavy sighthound (because of their long and soft coat).

For at least five centuries Russian nobility used borzoi dogs to hunt local wildlife.
And if in sixteenth century most nobles were living in the countryside, along with their people (but in manors instead of huts) and reasonably-sized packs of dogs that they genuinely cared about, and hunted with. In eighteenth-nineteenth centuries they mostly relocated to St. Petersburg and other cities, their lifestyle changed drastically, they were no longer living on the land they owned, the gap between them and their people grew larger and larger, along with their affinity for wealth and decadence.

Instead of having any kind of personal relationship with their dogs, they would employ various managers to build and maintain large kennels in their lands to compete with one another in “If Count Boris has 200 borzoi dogs, then I shall have 300!” meaningless displays of wealth. One of them (Samsonov of Smolensk) called himself “The Greatest Hunter” simply because his kennel had well over a thousand of dogs. This led to overbreeding and completely inadequate treatment of the aforementioned dogs. (More on that later). The only dogs that could truly be considered pets and companions at this point were the lucky ones that the owner of the kennel (or more likely his wife and children) picked during their rare visits to their owned lands.

"Hound hunting” turned into a bunch of rich city brats trotting along the road, talking about all the French thots they fucked on their last visit to Paris, while dozens (or even hundreds) of dogs with their hound masters would run around, chasing some poor fox (that was pre-captured, and then released specifically for the occasion, malnourished and weak).

More about mistreatment. It’s kinda hard to properly care for hundreds of dogs, when you are an illiterate 19th century fuck that never heard the words “cynology”, “zoology”, or even “biology”. Doing things “by heart” works when you only have a small number of dogs – but not on this industrial scale. Hence there were a lot of questionable practices, a number of fetishistic ones – some kennel masters forced young peasant mothers to nourish puppies, because human milk was supposed to “make them stronger” (but not cow or goat milk, obviously those wouldn’t work).

And some practices were downright abhorrent. For example, how do you train all of these dogs to hunt? They won’t get any better at chasing prey while howling in their cages, you DO have to set them loose somewhere, and you have two options.
First - the hard one, you can actually take them to the wild forests and fields of Russia, let them awaken their natural instincts by trying to chase and catch something out there. There is a considerable risk, however, of them running off and getting lost, despite your best efforts to control the pack.

And so, most kennel masters chose the second option, DO let them loose, but not in the wilds – right here, amongst the villages and crop fields. Let them trample the crops and chase after chickens, let them harass the peasants and their children. And if in a rare accident a borzoi strangles a peasant child to death – who cares? Serfs are much cheaper than puppies, so you warn them not to resist, or be lashed for daring to raise a hand against master’s dogs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Unsurprisingly, commoners had a problem with all of this, and many other things they experienced at the hands of their ‘betters’, since sometimes peasants were not “collateral damage” of borzoi hunting packs, but their actual intended targets, either for fun or to deal with a riot at hand. (The latter happened all the way to 1905 revolution)

When in 1861, after centuries of riots and bloodshed the serfdom was finally abolished, and Russian people got something that at least resembles human rights, two things happened that are largely the reason for the decline of borzoi population. First – your average aristocrat lost a considerable portion of their income, so no more frivolous activities like owning hundreds of dogs for hunting.

Second – the free peasants of Russia would no longer tolerate packs of hounds running around their villages, destroying crops, harassing livestock, posing threat to their children. They would take shovels, rakes and pitchforks and actively defend their livelihoods. This is mentioned by A. N. Engelhardt in his 1863 letter where he talks about the disappearance of hound hunting, saying that although conflicts between peasants and hunters/hound masters always did happen – usually the hunters would use the special horn they had to summon reinforcements and fuck up the peasant filth, but this approach no longer worked, too many peasants grew too bold to be bullied around. One such incident is depicted on a 1860s painting by Pyotr Sokolov (picrelated) - peasants assault hunters and their dogs, protecting their crops.

All of this happened long before Bolsheviks, when socialism in Russia was unheard of.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So, in the beginning of 20th century the population of borzoi was already well in decline, and the events that followed only accelerated said decline.

Russo-Japanese war, First World War, two Revolutions (three if you count the 1905 one) and a long Civil War – all of this took a toll on Russian population, and by extent – on their domesticated animals, but to say that there was some kind of a genocide perpetrated against this one breed because they were considered a symbol of aristocracy is ridiculous. Back then (during the Civil War) Bolsheviks had actual aristocrats and their armies to worry about.

And what about afterwards? Well, in 1930s the things calmed down (more or less) and in 1936 a Club for Borzoi Enthusiasts is registered under the All-Union Council of Physical Culture and Sports, so by that time there was a significant enough number of borzoi owners in the country for them to be recognized on a national level.

posts.name: TheUnamedPerson
posts.com: They can be quite resilient plants- plant a few of them near the base of a bushy tree or fence. It might take a year or two for them to start producing fruit. Water twice a week during dry spells. Good luck;)

They are protostomes which means the mouth forms before the anus in embryonic development. Humans are deuterostomes which means our anus forms before our mouth in embryonic development. A good way to immediately identify if an animal is a deuterostome or protostome is if the animal has bilateral symmetry and is anything other than a chordate, hemichordate, or echinoderm.

>>4397905
Big strong plant is mostly about getting enough light, water and warmth. As long as you fertilize at all it's usually enough. Slow release pellets are probably the easiest way. Or you could microdose fertilizer with every watering.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4397905
Most house plants are light starved and even if they get enough, you can still boost their growth with a longer photoperiod. 20h of light and a 4h night is ideal for building both size and plant mass. As for fertilizer, you should make sure they get enough Mg and Ca, as many fertilizers only have NPK. How much you fertilize is really not an exact science, you'll have to experiment. But most plants can take way more fertilizer than you think. Just make sure to water them with rainwater now and then to flush out all the excess salts. Airy substrate (perlite, bark, leca, etc are your friends) is a must so the roots don't rot. I'd look into what the hydroponics guys have written up on the net, they've got fertilizing down to a science.

posts.com:
>>4400045
Any Nepenthes hybrid with truncata in it. You're in the US, most likely? Presumptiously, here's a link to what you need https://www.carnivero.com/a/search?q=truncata&sort_by=price-ascending

(if you're an europoor like me, I recommend wistuba.com most highly)

Pick whichever one you like best. These will grow huge (talking a few feet across with foot tall pitchers, truncata hybrids regularly catch mice in greenhouses) and can take a beating. One with "veitchii" in it if you want it to withstand extra low humidity, but all of these will pitcher on the windowsill if you meet their light demands. Pot in airy substrate mix with perlite, pine bark and sphagnum moss. Fertilize by dumping fertilizer in the pitchers. Happy growing!

posts.com:
Would it be possible to grow Water Hyacinth in a hydro stone aquaponics system?

>But why?
I want to install a duck pond, with a filtering mechanism.
It pumps from the pond, to a solids filter, then to hydrostone bed which would grow duck feed.
Water Hyacinth propagate quickly so it makes good duck feed, but there needs to be a soilless media (Hydrostone or lava rocks) to act as a secondary filter before the water falls back into the pond.
>Why not grow the feed in the pond itself
The ducks would decimate it before it could grow to any decent size

>>4409072
Pic.
Doesn't frost here, "growing season" for annuals is reversed here too. Summer literally everything burns up, "winter" is when everything flowers and grows.

I was even considering beekeeping until I discovered that:
1. Western "beekeeper" bees literally cannot survive the summer. Most beekeepers drag their boxes to a cooler area up the mountains for 2 months per year.
2. Local wild bees only build open-air (i.e. you can't beekeep them), despite the inherent safety/security issues it's the ONLY way they can survive the insane temperatures

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4395462
Solution of neem oil, 2-3 drops of Dawn unscented dish soap, 1-2 drops of peppermint extract, water. Maybe 3 parts water for every 1 part neem oil. This solution is safe for pets, children, and basically anything that is not an insect. Begin byy spraying the mixed up solution into the soil until decently moist if not wet. Wait a week or so and see if populations have decreased. Repeat in soil weekly until they are gone. If the problem persists, purchase some plant dusting gloves and spray your hands with the solution, then wipe down the leaves. The undersides are most important.

I have successfully removed fungus gnats from my home 3-4 times using this method over the last decade or so.

posts.com:
>>4415734
Light is light. A tiny led is obviously nothing compared to a giant explosion in the sky, but situating it close enough to a leaf allows enough usable light particles to reach the plant and allow photosynthesis.
Vitamin d is matter of uv, and your plants don't want too much of it anyway, just like you, unless you're into cancer and blindness.
More serious led lights add some minimal uv leds of shallow almost visible specter to stimulate some specific fruiting and flowering plants.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415339
With indoor plants, 95 per cent of it is getting enough light and water.
People struggle to grow big indoor plants like that big Monstera simply because they don't water them deeply. People don't want water running all over their floor, so they only put a little dribble of water on the top of the pot. Then the plants can only develop shallow roots and can't grow properly.
To get a nice, big, lush houseplant you need to water it regularly and deeply so that water comes pissing out of the holes in the bottom of the pot.
The only real way to do this is to take it outside on a trolley and water it with a hose (or to water it in the shower or bathtub, taking care not to block your drains with soil).
Re staking: Over time your little Monstera will grow towards its main light source, like pic related. You can minimise this by turning the pot 90 degrees every week or so.
When putting a stake in to hold it up, try to minimise the damage to the roots. Pick one place to put the stake in and just leave it there. If you keep pulling stakes out and pushing them back in you're just damaging more roots for no reason.
It looks like your Monstera is going really well so far. Well done!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4420665
>>4420667
You can't really relate the body plan of a plant to animals. They diverged too long ago for that. The most primitive plants, mosses and liverworts, don't have roots or flowers at all. They're basically a mass of photosynthesis capable cells that can regenerate from even a tiny cutting.

If you want to gain an appreciation for plants, I'd look into their history foremost. They were the first living things to leave the oceans and conquer the land, in the process they literally terraformed the whole planet. Mosses covered the world, pumping the atmosphere full of oxygen. For fifty million years trees ruled the continents, there weren't even organisms capable of breaking down wood yet. Dead trees simply built up on the forest floor, their mighty corpses totally impervious to other life (this is the origin of coal btw). All complex life relies on plants binding the suns energy through photosynthesis.

Human culture itself only really came about once we settled down and started tending to plants. Surely this is also where some part of our fascination with them stems from. For ten thousand years, our lives and civilizations were (and continue to be) dependent on people living in sync with their crop plants. Deep knowledge of plants and their culture has been passed down for generations, one the most essential things for survival. Only the peoples of the world who paid close attention to the life and growth of plants could ever build and achieve anything truly great.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4422715
>whats the best way to germinate seeds
It really depends on the seed, but the paper towel in a plastic bag method is a very easy way for larger seeds (like citrus, coffee, ice cream bean, etc). Basically you moisten a paper towel, put your seeds on it, fold it so it covers the seeds on both sides, put it in a (re)sealable plastic bag, put that somewhere warm and wait a bit. You'll soon start to see some seeds get mouldy, throw those away. The other seeds will send out their first root and soon after their cotyledon(s). At that point, take them out of the bag and put them in wet potting mix, and your seedlings are ready to grow.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4424099
>>4424143
Removing the old medium makes sense if you're putting into something different, for example if the old medium is less water retentive than the new one, it could happen that your plant would not be able to get enough water despite the new soil being moist. By removing the old soil or at least mixing it in with the new soil, you avoid this issue. If your plant is newly bought, it's always a good idea to remove the soil to check if it's in a so-called 'death plug'. Many growers put seedlings or cuttings in pure peat and wrap it with a piece of supposedly (but not really) degradable fabric, and as the seedlings grow, they just put those 'plugs' in regular potting mix. For a short while, this works, but especially for succulents this usually means that they'll die from overwatering because the peat just stays soaking wet for much longer than the rest of the soil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4425593
There was no need to prune the branches, as many Adenium go dormant in winter and lose most or all of their foliage anyway. As long as the caudex (not a bulb) is firm, it's still alive and waiting for the growing season. Keep it on the dry side until it sends out some new branches, then you can water it pretty much as often as you want.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4426252
>Even when it's in it's growing season you only want to water it every two weeks or so
As long as they're in a sunny spot you can genuinely water them as much as you like. They're tropicals that survived the desertification of their habitat, and they have no problems growing in tropical conditions (rich soil, high humidity, lots of rain) year-round. An Adenium will only rot if it's wet and cold, or if the soil is actually waterlogged.

That doesn't mean they won't grow with less water, but it'll take much longer to get a nice looking plant, and you'll never get as many flowers.

Also see this article:
https://adenium.tucsoncactus.org/large.html

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4426951
portulacaria afra, better known as the elephant bush is a great choice. Don't let your cat munch on it all day because that's not good for the plant, but they're nontoxic to people and animals and are actually eaten in soups and salads in South Africa where they grow natively. They're also virtually indestructible, they like more water than most succulents but they can still survive a good 3 weeks without water just fine. And since overwatering is far and away the number one killer for succulents having a plant that can tolerate that a bit better isn't a bad idea.

You can buy them very small and keep them that way, but they can eventually reach sizes upwards of 6 feet tall with gigantic woody branches if you plant them outdoors in a place that never freezes or keep repotting them every year for a few decades.

Just only water it when the leaves get a bit soft to the touch, which usually takes around 10-14 days, and plant it in really well draining soil in a pot that has a drain hole. Other than that just stick it in the sunniest window you can find and it'll outlive you.

Jade plants are very similar and a bit cooler in my opinion, but they're marginally harder to take care of because they're a bit more sensitive to overwatering (they're still extremely hard to kill), and they're mildly toxic to cats and people. They aren't "if you/your cat takes one bite they're a goner" toxic, but although they're not likely to kill your cat it certainly wouldn't be fun for them.

>>4426874
No, it looks like shit because they're pruning it like a hedge. It won't die though. Some of those stubs will die back, you'll get a bunch of new growth growing at crazy angles from the ones that don't. The problem will compound itself over and over until the thing gets so top heavy it falls over or it runs out of gas and dies.

You're supposed to select a few good canes to keep and cut the rest back to the ground every year. It's really not complex or difficult, just tell your gardener not to touch your roses. Honestly the structure is so lousy on this one you'd be better off just starting over.
